Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Audio/Video Documentation of Itelmen [itl]

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Itelmen is a highly endangered language spoken natively by fewer than 20 individuals on the Kamchatka peninsula in Russia. The primary goal of this project is to compile multimedia (audio and video) support for a dictionary of the language. The project will record as much material as possible with the remaining speakers, supplementing small existing collections, and making annotated audio and video recordings available for posterity (both for scholars and for community members) with digital archives in both Russia and the U.S. A component of the project involves the development of software for language archiving and analysis.

Itelmen has many rare typological features, which make these recordings of interest to linguistic scholarship, both narrowly (shedding light on the structure and history of the Chukotko-Kamchatkan language family), and broadly, to the field of linguistics as a whole (especially in the areas of morphology, phonology and typology), as well as related areas such as linguistic anthropology. The project includes training of graduate students in the US and in the field, as well as the training of a member of the Itelmen community in techniques of language documentation and revitalization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Itelmen language [itl] is spoken natively by fewer than a dozen members of the Itelmen community, an indigenous group on Russia’s Kamchatka Peninsula that once numbered perhaps 15-20,000 (Volodin 2002:27). This fascinating language represents a unique manifestation of the world’s cultural and linguistic heritage that is at imminent risk of disappearing forever. Our project was part of an ongoing, international (Russia, Japan, US) collaborative effort to collect and edit multimedia documentation of the language while there are still native speakers, and to make that data available to scholars (linguistics, anthropology), to members of the Itelmen community, and ultimately to the interested public.

 

Within the larger collaboration, the University of Connecticut team has been primarily involved in the ‘back-end’ of the project. We have made significant progress in assembling and editing an array of documentary material, and preparing that material for eventual inclusion in the ‘front-end’, public-facing platform (online), currently in beta-version and nearing completion under the University of Alaska-led collaborative portion of the overall project.

 

A major output of the project will be a browser-based repository with audio and video materials, accompanied by time-aligned transcriptions and translations, keyed to a searchable dictionary. In addition, the dictionary, in coordination with a larger comprehensive dictionary project, will have a few thousand playable audio samples of words and phrases in Itelmen, as spoken by native speakers. The UConn phase of the project has provided a significant component of the underlying data for this project, while our collaborators have developed the software to make this browser-accessible, both web-based and in a stand-alone version, usable within the community where internet access is not guaranteed. All material is also being prepared for archiving at multiple sites, including the LangueDOC archives—the major archiving site for the indigenous languages of Russia. In the course of this work, we have contributed to the development of (non-commercial, open source) software innovations that facilitate interoperability among various components, notably including linguistic database software and language archiving software.

 

Project members have transcribed and edited nearly 100 hours of previously existing audio and video recordings, and added more than 25 hours of new recordings. We have additionally begun the task of analyzing and transcribing recently rediscovered wax cylinder recordings from the early 20th century.

 

Over the course of the project, 6 graduate research assistants have received valuable training in the documentation of endangered languages. Three former research assistants are currently engaged in projects in this area, drawing on their training in this team. Tatiana Degai, a member of the Itelmen community and key member of this NSF project, is completing doctoral studies on endangered language revitalization, and is employed in this area in Kamchatka. In addition to academic presentations, project members have addressed public audiences on issues of language endangerment and revitalization, including presentations at the United Nations, and in the media.

 

In addition to the community-facing aspects of the project, Itelmen language material collected and analyzed over the course of our research has provided a rich basis for a series of theoretical and descriptive linguistic studies, some of which we have published over the course of the grant period, and others of which are in planning and preparation stages.
